tit.e: Chinju-fu Shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North)
tit.cmt: 固有名詞は原則統一用語に従いました。
tit.e: Chinju-fu Shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North)
Chinju-fu Shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North)

sen.j: 鎮守府将軍（ちんじゅふしょうぐん）は、日本の奈良時代から平安時代にかけて北辺の防衛のためにおかれた令外官の官職の将軍である。
sen.e: Chinju-fu Shogun (鎮守府将軍: Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North) was an official who served as shogun, belonging to Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system), which was set up for the defense of the northern area during the Nara Period and the Heian Period in Japan.

Chinju-fu Shogun (鎮守府将軍: Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North) was an official who served as shogun, belonging to Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system), which was set up for the defense of the northern area during the Nara Period and the Heian Period in Japan.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Chinju-fu Shogun was an official who served as shogun, belonging to Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system), which was set up for the defense of the northern area during the Nara period and the Heian period in Japan.
sen.cmt: 漢字および英訳をのぞき、表記を変えました。

tit.cmt: 語頭を大文字にしました。
FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 鎮守府将軍の始まりを直接記した史料はないが、知られる限りでは大野東人がもっとも古く、彼が初代の鎮守府将軍であったといわれている。
sen.e: Although there is no written materials referring directly to the beginning of Chinju-fu Shogun, it has been said that the first Chinju-fu Shogun was ONO no Azumabito, whose appearance in the history was the oldest one as far as we can know.

Although there are no written materials referring directly to the beginning of Chinju-fu Shogun, it has been said that the first Chinju-fu Shogun was ONO no Azumabito, whose appearance in history was the oldest as far as we can know.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Although there are no historical records referring directly to the origins of the Chinju-fu Shogun, it has been said that the first Chinju-fu Shogun was ONO no Azumabito, who is as we can know the oldest.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 司令部ははじめ「鎮所」、のちに「鎮守府 (古代)」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: At first, the headquarters was called '鎮所 (Shizumedokoro)' at first and later 'Chinju-fu (ancient).'
sen.cmt: 「鎮所」→定訳不明・読み不明： '鎮所 (Shizumedokoro)' としました。
sen.e: At first, the headquarters was called '鎮所 (Shizumedokoro)' and later 'Chinju-fu (ancient).'
sen.cmt: grammar, redundancy
sen.e: At first, the headquarters was called 'chinjo' and later 'Chinju-fu.'
sen.cmt: 鎮所の読みを変えました。 (古代)はポップアップヒントのテキストのため、のぞきました。

sen.j: 神亀元年（724年）に多賀（多賀城）に城柵が築かれてからは、その地に置かれたと推定される。
sen.e: In 724, when a josaku (an official defense site) was built in Taga (Taga-jo Castle), it is said to have been set up there.
sen.cmt: 城柵→定訳不明：josaku (an official defense site)としました。
sen.e: In 724, a josaku (an official defense site) was built in Taga (Taga-jo Castle).
sen.cmt: redundant
sen.e: It is assumed that in the year 724 a fortress (Taga-jo Castle) was built located in Taga.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 多賀にはまた陸奥国府が置かれていた。
sen.e: Mutsu-kokufu (the provincial capital of Mutsu Province) was also located in Taga.
Mutsu-kokufu (the provincial capital of Mutsu Province) was also located in Taga.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Mutsu-kokufu (the provincial office of Mutsu Province) was also located in Taga.
sen.cmt: 用語を他の記事に合わせました。

sen.j: 鎮守府将軍は、陸奥国と出羽国の兵士と他国から来て両国に駐屯する兵士を指揮し、陸奥国と出羽国の軍事を統括する任にあたっていた。
sen.e: Chinju-fu Shogun were taking the overall control of the military affairs in Mutsu Province and Dewa Province, commanding the local soldiers of Mutsu and Dewa Provinces as well as those who were from other provinces to station there.

Chinju-fu Shogun were taking the overall control of the military affairs in Mutsu and Dewa Provinces, commanding the local samurai of Mutsu and Dewa Provinces as well as those who were from other provinces and stationed there.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: The Chinju-fu Shogun took overall control of military affairs in Mutsu and Dewa Provinces and, commanded samurai from both provinces as well as samurai posted from other provinces.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 「将軍」と名がつくものは、鎮守府将軍を除けば臨時の官職だったので、鎮守府将軍は平時にただ一人の将軍であった。
sen.e: Except for Chinju-fu Shogun, all the other official posts with the title 'shogun' were interim ones, and, therefore, Chinju-fu Shogun was the only shogun existed in peacetime.
sen.cmt: 臨時の(官職)→定訳不明：interim (official posts)としました。
sen.e: Except for Chinju-fu Shogun, all the other official posts with the title 'shogun' were interim ones, and, therefore, Chinju-fu Shogun was the only shogun existing in peacetime.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Except for Chinju-fu Shogun, all the other official posts with the title 'shogun' were interim ones, and, therefore, Chinju-fu Shogun was the only shogun existing in peacetime.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: しばしば管轄地域を同じくする陸奥按察使が兼ねて政軍両権をあわせた。
sen.e: This post was often occupied by Mutsu no Azechi (the inspector of the provincial government of Mutsu), and he covered the same jurisdiction, he gripped the both of the political and military authorities.
This post was often occupied by Mutsu no Azechi (the inspector of the provincial government of Mutsu), and he covered the same jurisdiction, with his grip on both political and military authorities.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Regional jurisdictional control often rested with the Mutsu region Azechi (inspector) who concurrently served as the political and military authority.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 鎮守府将軍が対峙したのは陸奥国と出羽国の北にいた蝦夷であった。
sen.e: The target of Chinju-fu Shogun was the Ezo living in the northern parts of Mutsu and Dewa Provinces.
The target of Chinju-fu Shogun was the Ezo living in the northern parts of Mutsu and Dewa Provinces.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Chinju-fu (northern defenses) Shogun confronted the Ezo people of Mutsu and Dewa Provinces in the north of Honshu (Japan's main island)..
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 大きな軍事行動が必要になると、中央から派遣されたさまざまな臨時の将軍・大将軍が他国からの兵とともに来着し、鎮守府将軍を指揮下におさめた。
sen.e: When a big military action was required various interim shogun (generals) and dai shogun (great generals) dispatched from the central government arrived with the soldiers from other provinces, lead Chinju-fu Shogun under their control.
sen.cmt: 大将軍→dai shogun (great generals) 用語統一リストでは、Dai Shogunと単語最初の文字が大文字でしたが、10.19付け統一用語リストセル６: Shogunの項に従い文中での使用のため小文字にしました。
sen.e: When a large military action was required various interim shogun (generals) and dai shogun (great generals) dispatched from the central government arrived with the samurai from other provinces, with the lead Chinju-fu Shogun under their control.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: When a large military movements was required various ad-hoc shoguns (generals) and dai shogun (great generals) were dispatched from the central government (along with soldiers from other provinces) all of which came under the command of the Chinju-fu (Northern defenses) Shogun.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 『万葉集』の編纂者とされている大伴家持は、鎮守将軍在任中の延暦4年（785年）にこの地で病死している。
sen.e: Yakamochi OTOMO, who is said to be the editor of "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves), died of a disease in 785 in this land, while he was serving as Chinju-fu Shogun.
Yakamochi OTOMO, who is said to be the editor of "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves), died of a disease in 785 in this land, while he was serving as Chinju-fu Shogun.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: OTOMO no Yakamochi (believed to be compiler of the Japanese classic book "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves)), died of illness in the year 785 in the provinces while he was campaigning as Chinju-fu Shogun.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

tit.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 征夷大将軍の坂上田村麻呂は、延暦21年（802年）に胆沢城を、延暦22年（803年）に志波城を築いた。
sen.e: Chinju-fu Shogun SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro built Izawa-jo Castle in 802, and Shiwa-jo Castle in 803.
Chinju-fu Shogun SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro built Izawa-jo Castle in 802, and Shiwa-jo Castle in 803.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro who was Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), built Isawa-jo Castle in the year 802, and Shiwa-jo Castle in 803.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 築城と同時か数年後に鎮守府は胆沢に移転した。
sen.e: When the castles were constructed or several yeas later, Chinzei-fu moved to Izawa.
When the castles were constructed or several years later, Chinzei-fu moved to Izawa.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: The Chinju-fu (Northern defenses base) was relocated to Isawa either at the same time the castles were built or, possibly some years later.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 正確にいつかは不明である。
sen.e: The precise date is now known.
The precise date is now known.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: The precise date is unknown.
sen.cmt: unknownとしました。

sen.j: 胆沢の前に志波に置かれた時期があったかもしれないともいわれる。
sen.e: According to a theory, before moving to Izawa, it was located in Shiwa.
According to a theory, before moving to Izawa, it was located in Shiwa.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: It is thought that prior to being relocated to Isawa, it was possibly located in Shiwa.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 以後の鎮守府将軍は、陸奥国府から離れて胆沢で勤務することになった。
sen.e: Afterwards, Chinzei-fu Shogun left the provincial capital of Mutsu (Mutsu-kokufu) and started working in Izawa.
Afterwards, Chinzei-fu Shogun left the provincial capital of Mutsu (Mutsu-kokufu) and started working in Izawa.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Subsequent Chinju-fu Shoguns distanced themselves from the Mutsu provincial government and started working in Isawa.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 移転以前の鎮守府将軍は国司の上に立って北方の鎮めにつく役職であった。
sen.e: Before its transfer, Chinzei-fu Shogun was the post to take in charge of the defense in the northern areas, however, after the backset of 'expedition against the barbarians or Ezo people), it became to control only a part of Mutsu Province, that means the post was degraded and ranked a little lower ranked than Kokushi (the governor of Mutsu Province).

Before its transfer, Chinzei-fu Shogun was a post in charge of defense of the northern areas, however, after the backset of 'expedition against the barbarians or Ezo people, it came to control only a part of Mutsu Province, that means the post was degraded and ranked a little lower than Kokushi (the governor of Mutsu Province).
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Prior to this relocation, the Chinju-fu (Northern defenses) Shogun outranked the Kokushi (provincial governor) and was posted to pacify the Northern provinces.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、「征夷」の停滞後は陸奥国の一部を管轄することになり、陸奥国司よりやや格が下がることになった。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: However, after the stalemate of the `Barbarian Campaigns` (`Sei-i`), the Chinju-fu post came to control only a part of Mutsu Province, meaning a demotion to a status somewhat lower than the governor of Mutsu Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 行政官化した将軍の職権が国司の職権と重複する部分もあった。
sen.e: Shogun's scope of work and that of Kokushi sometimes overlapped, and a severe conflict often occurred between the shogun and the governor (Kokushi).
The shogun's scope of work and that of Kokushi sometimes overlapped, and a severe conflict often occurred between the shogun and the governor (Kokushi).
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Elements of the shogun executive bailiwick and that of the provincial governs overlapped sometimes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 将軍と国司の激しい対立がしばしば起きた。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Intense confrontations frequently occurred between shoguns and provincial governors.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: このため、鎮守府将軍は早期に事実上名誉職化し、鎮守府に居ることも少なく、鎮守府は国府より早く廃絶した。
sen.e: Therefore, Chinju-fu Shogun had practically converted into an honorary post, and as the shogun seldom stayed in Chinjufu, this post was abolished earlier than Kokufu.
sen.cmt: 鎮守府→Chinjufu 鎮守府将軍はChinju-fuとなっていますが国府がKokufuと表記されているので、ハイフンをとりました。
sen.e: Therefore, Chinju-fu Shogun had practically converted into an honorary post, and as the shogun seldom stayed in Chinjufu, this post was abolished earlier than Kokufu.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: As such, the Chinju-fu Shogun role was for all intents and purposes converted into an honorary post, and as the shogun seldom stayed in Chinju-fu (Northern bases), the Chinju-fu (Northern bases) were abolished earlier than the provincial governments.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、前九年の役、後三年の役の発生により、現地の指揮官として出羽国にも及ぶ軍事指揮権を与えられ復活する。
sen.e: However, as the Zenkumen War (the Early Nine Years' War) and the Gosannen War (the Later Three Years' War) occurred, the post was recovered as the local commander with the far-reaching military jurisdiction even to Dewa Province

However, as the Zenkumen War (the Early Nine Year War) and the Gosannen War (the Later Three Year War) occurred, the post was reestablished as the local commander with the far-reaching military jurisdiction even to Dewa Province
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: However, with the outbreak of the Zenkunen War (the Early Nine Year War) and the Gosannen Wars (the Later Three Year War), the local military command role was revived as a local commander with sweeping military jurisdiction even in Dewa Province.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 鎮守府が実質的に機能しなくなってから、鎮守府将軍は優れた武士に与えられる名誉職的なものになった。
sen.e: Since Chinzeifu had practically been defunct, Chinzei-fu Shogun became a post given to an excellent samurai as an honorary post.
Since Chinzeifu had practically been defunct, Chinzei-fu Shogun became a post given to an excellent samurai as an honorary post.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Since Chinju-fu (Northern defense) functions had been substantially pared-back, the honorary post of Chinju-fu Shogun post was awarded to distinguished samurai.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

tit.cmt: 語頭を大文字にしました。

sen.j: ちなみに、武門の栄職として、歴代の源氏の大将も叙任された。
sen.e: The successive Taisho (generals) of Genji (Minamoto clan) had been appointed to the post, which was considered as a laureate position in the samurai society.
The successive Taisho (generals) of the Genji (Minamoto clan) had been appointed to the post, considered as a laureate position in samurai society.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Incidentally, as an honorary post earmarked for military families, the post was filled by successive Taisho (generals) hailing from the Minamoto clan.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 清和源氏では、初代 源経基以来、源氏の大将の多くが任ぜられ、経基王の嫡男源満仲や満仲の子にあたる源頼光、源頼信はその好例である。
sen.e: Many of the generals (Taisho) of Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan), starting from MINAMOTO no Tsunetomo I, took the post, and MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, the legitimate son of Tsunemoto-o or Tsunemoto I, and MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu and MINAMOTO no Yorinobu, sons of Mitsunaka, are such good examples.
sen.cmt: 経基王→定訳不明：Tsunemoto-o or Tsunemoto I としました。
sen.e: Many of the generals (Taisho) of Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan), starting from MINAMOTO no Tsunetomo I, took the post, and MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, the legitimate son of Tsunemoto-o or Tsunemoto I, and MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu and MINAMOTO no Yorinobu, sons of Mitsunaka, are good examples.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Many of the Taisho (Generals) of the Seiwa-Genji clan (starting with the clan founder MINAMOTO no Tsunetomo), took the Chinju-fu Shogun post, and MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka (legitimate son of Tsunemoto-o (or Tsunemoto)), MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu and, MINAMOTO no Yorinobu (sons of Mitsunaka) are good examples of the practice.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 殊に頼信の家系である河内源氏は頼信をはじめ、子 源頼義と孫源義家に至るまでこの重職に叙せられていた。
sen.e: Especially Kawachi-Genji, Yorinobu's family line, enjoyed this important position from generation to generation, starting from Yorinobu to his son MINAMOTO no Yoriyoshi and his grandson MINAMOTO no Yoshiie.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Especially the Kawachi-Genji, Yorinobu family line, enjoyed this important position from generation to generation, starting from Yorinobu to his son MINAMOTO no Yoriyoshi and his grandson MINAMOTO no Yoshiie.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: In particular, the Yorinobu family line in the Kawachi-Genji clan availed itself of this important position from generation to generation, starting with Yorinobu who handed the role to his son MINAMOTO no Yoriyoshi from whence the role passed to his grandson MINAMOTO no Yoshiie.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 源義家は源氏の祖経基以来、自らの代まで5代続けての叙任であった。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoshiie is the fifth generation since the founder Tsunemoto to take this post.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoshiie is the fifth generation since the founder Tsunemoto to have taken this post.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoshiie was the fifth successive generation after Tsunemoto (founder of Minamoto clan) to assume this post.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: このことは義家と祖先たちの武名と交わり、武家の棟梁 源氏の名を高めることとなった。
sen.e: This fact elevated the name of Genji (Minamoto clan) as the leading warrior, supported, in addition, by Yoshiie and other ancestors' excellent achievements as samurai.
This fact elevated the name of Genji (Minamoto clan) as the leading warrior, supported, in addition, by Yoshiie and other ancestors' excellent achievements as samurai.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: This practice added cachet to the Minamoto clan name as a samurai family, to its ancestors and the founder of the clan, Yoshiie.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 鎮守府将軍職は、源頼朝が征夷大将軍となって以降、事実上無名化したが、建武の新政下において鎮守府将軍職が再び置かれることとなり、北畠顕家などが叙任された。
sen.e: The post of Chinju-fu Shogun had practically faded into obscurity, since MINAMOTO no Yoritomo became Seii taishogun (literally, 'great general who subdues the barbarians'), but in the Kenmu Restoration, the post of Chinju-fu Shogun was recovered and Akiie KITABATAKE among others was appointed.
sen.cmt: 征夷大将軍→Seii taishogun (literally, 'great general who subdues the barbarians') 用語リストでは"great general who subdues the barbarians"が使われていましたが、シングル' ' で表記しました。
sen.e: The post of Chinju-fu Shogun had practically faded into obscurity, since MINAMOTO no Yoritomo became Seii taishogun (literally, 'great general who subdues the barbarians'), but in the Kenmu Restoration, the post of Chinju-fu Shogun was reestablished and Akiie KITABATAKE among others was appointed.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: The post of Chinju-fu (Northern bases) Shogun largely faded into obscurity after MINAMOTO no Yoritomo became Seii taishogun (unifying commander-in-chief) however, during the period of the Kenmu Restoration, the post of Chinju-fu Shogun was reestablished and held by Akiie KITABATAKE and others.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: この人事は官位相当制を無視したものであったため、顕家の父、北畠親房が、三位以上の公卿がこの職に任官する際には「鎮守大将軍」と呼称し征夷大将軍と同格とすることを奏請し、認められている。
sen.e: Since this personal arrangement did not follow the corresponding official rank system, Akiie's father, Chikafusa KITABATAKE made a petition to the imperial court to use the word 'Chinju taishogun' (Chinju great general), appositive to Seii taishogun, for a court noble ranked more than Sanmi (Third Rank) when he took this post, and his petition was accepted.
sen.cmt: 「鎮守大将軍」→定訳不明：'Chinju taishogun' （Chinju great general)としました。三位→定訳不明： Sanmi (Third Rank) 正三位or従三位の別が分からなかったので、そのままSanmiとしました。
sen.e: Since this personal arrangement did not follow the corresponding official ranking system, Akiie's father, Chikafusa KITABATAKE made a petition to the imperial court to use the word 'Chinju taishogun' (Chinju great general), appositive to Seii taishogun, for a court noble ranked more than Sanmi (Third Rank) when he took this post, and his petition was accepted.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Since the official ranking system ignored this executive role in a personnel sense, Chikafusa KITABATAKE (Akiie's father) successfully petitioned the imperial court to use the title 'Chinju taishogun' (Northern bases great general) on equal ranking to the title Seii taishogun (Unifying commander-in-chief) in circumstances when court nobles ranked above Sanmi (Third Rank) assumed this post.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 南北朝時代以降、鎮守府将軍は叙任をみることはなくなったが、後に新田氏の祖となる源義重が南朝方の功臣として活躍した新田義貞の祖である理由をもって贈鎮守府将軍として記録されていることから没後、贈官を受けたものと考えられる。
sen.e: Since the period of Northern and Southern Courts, no new appointment to Chinju-fu Shogun was undertaken, but it is recorded that MINAMOTO no Yoshishige, who later founded the Nitta clan, was granted Chinju-fu Shogun because he was an ancestor of Yoshisada NITTA, who contributed actively as a meritorious retainer to Southern Court, although the grant of the post seems to have taken place after his death.
sen.cmt: 功臣→定訳不明：meritorious retainerとしました。
sen.e: Since the period of Northern and Southern Courts, no new appointment to Chinju-fu Shogun were undertaken, but it is recorded that MINAMOTO no Yoshishige, who later founded the Nitta clan, was granted Chinju-fu Shogun because he was an ancestor of Yoshisada NITTA, who contributed actively as a meritorious retainer to the Southern Court, although the grant of the post seems to have taken place after his death.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Subsequent to the Northern and Southern Courts period in Japan (circa 1336-92), no new Chinju-fu Shogun appointments were made however, there are records that MINAMOTO no Yoshishige (later founder of the Nitta clan) was appointed Chinju-fu Shogun by virtue he was an ancestor of Yoshisada NITTA (an active and meritorious retainer of the Southern Court) who had been appointed posthumously.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: さて、鎮守府将軍の職は鎌倉時代以降、一時期の例外を除いて事実上、廃絶された官職となったが、その官職の意義は後世まで生きた。
sen.e: After the Kamakura Period, the post of Chinju-fu Shogun became practically an abolished official post, except for a certain period of time, however, the significance of the post had survived after ages.

After the Kamakura Period, the post of the Chinju-fu Shogun became practically an abolished official post, except for a certain period of time, however, the significance of the post had survived the ages.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: From the Kamakura period onwards, the Chinju-fu Shogun role became defunct except for a certain period of time, however, the significance of the role survived for posterity.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 天皇、皇族、大臣や門跡の居所を御所というが、将軍もまたその居所を御所と称した。
sen.e: The domicile of Emperor, Imperial Family, Ministers, and Monzeki (a chief priest born of the Imperial Family or of the nobility) is called Gosho (Imperial Palace), but the residence of shogun was also called Gosho.

The domicile of Emperor, Imperial Family, Ministers, and Monzeki (a chief priest born of the Imperial Family or of the nobility) is called Gosho (Imperial Palace), but the residence of shogun was also called Gosho.
sen.cmt: OK
sen.e: The term `Gosho` (residence/palace/manor) was the term used for the domiciles of emperors, the imperial family, government ministers, and Monzeki (chief priests of imperial or noble lineage) as well as the term of reference used for the residence of a shogun.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 通常、皇室か三位以上の公卿にのみ敬称された御所の敬称は、従五位下に位する鎮守府将軍にも用いられた。
sen.e: Generally, an honorific title applied for the Imperial Family members or nobles ranked more than Sanmi (Third Rank) was also used for Chinju-fu Shogun, which was ranked Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).
sen.cmt: 三位→Sanmi (Third Rank) 正、従の別がわからないのでこうしました。
sen.e: Generally, an honorific title applied for Imperial Family members or nobles that were ranked more than Sanmi (Third Rank) was also used for Chinju-fu Shogun, ranked Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: The honorific `gosho' residence term was usually used by imperial family members and nobles ranked higher than Sanmi (Third Rank) but, was also used by a Chinju-fu Shogun, of imperial Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) rank.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 藤原秀衡はその居所を柳之御所と称したが、鎮守大将軍となった北畠顕家、北畠顕信の子孫はそれぞれ北畠氏、浪岡氏となり、顕家の子孫は袰綿御所、浪岡御所、川原御所と称し、顕信の子孫は多芸御所などと称した。
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Hidehira called his residence Yanagi no Gosho (Yanagi Palace), and when the descendents of Akiie KITABATAKE and Akinobu KITABATAKE formed the Kitabatake clan and the Namioka clan respectively, the descendents of Akiie called their residences Horowata-gosho, Namioka-gosho and Kawara-gosho, and the descendents of Akinobu used the name Tagi-gosho, etc.
sen.cmt: 以下の「御所」はXxx-goshoとハイフンでつなぎ、（Xxx Palace）は省きました。
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Hidehira called his residence Yanagi no Gosho (Yanagi Palace), and when the descendents of Akiie KITABATAKE and Akinobu KITABATAKE formed the Kitabatake clan and the Namioka clan respectively, the descendents of Akiie called their residences Horowata-gosho, Namioka-gosho and Kawara-gosho, and the descendents of Akinobu used the name Tagi-gosho, etc.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Hidehira called his residence `Yanagi no Gosho` (Willow Palace), and when the descendents of Akiie KITABATAKE formed the Kitabatake clan and Akinobu KITABATAKE descendents the Namioka clan, Akiie's descendents gave their residences the names `Horowata-gosho`, `Namioka-gosho` and `Kawara-gosho`, whereas the descendents of Akinobu named their residences `Tagi-gosho` etc.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 足利将軍家の一門では、征夷大将軍の同族ということを由来するものの、鎮守府将軍源義家の子孫である、吉良氏の一門はそれぞれ丸山御所、世田谷御所、蒔田御所、勝見御所、斯波氏の一門は斯波御所、雫石御所、猪去御所を称した。
sen.e: Among the Ashikaga Shogun Family, the Kira clan, the descendents of Chinju-fu Shogun MINAMOTO no Yoshiie used the denomination of gosho (palace), like Maruyama-gosho, Setagaya-gosho, Makita-gosho, Katsumi-gosho respectively, based on the pretext that they had a kinship with Seii taishogun, and the families of the Shiba clan, gave the name of Shiba-gosho, Shizukuishi-gosho, Isari-gosho to their residences.

Among the Ashikaga Shogun Family, the Kira clan, the descendents of Chinju-fu Shogun MINAMOTO no Yoshiie used the denomination of gosho (palace), like Maruyama-gosho, Setagaya-gosho, Makita-gosho, Katsumi-gosho respectively, based on the pretext that they had a kinship with Seii taishogun, and the families of the Shiba clan, gave the name of Shiba-gosho, Shizukuishi-gosho, Isari-gosho to their residences.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: The family of Ashikaga Shoguns used the pretext that they had a kinship with Seii taishogun (Unifying commander-in-chiefs)), Kira clan families held they were descendents of Chinju-fu (northern bases) Shogun MINAMOTO no Yoshiie and thus named their residences: Maruyama-gosho, Setagaya-gosho, Makita-gosho, and Katsumi-gosho whereas the families of the Shiba clan, gave their residences the titles: Shiba-gosho, Shizukuishi-gosho, Isari-gosho.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: また北畠氏の家臣となった庶家においても、木造御所 木造氏、大河内御所 大河内氏、藤方御所 藤方氏、坂内御所 坂内氏、波瀬御所、田丸御所 田丸氏、岩内御所 岩内氏などと称した。
sen.e: In addition, even common vassalic houses of the Kitabatake clan also named their residences using the denomination, gosho and clan, as follows: Kozukuri-gosho, Kozukuri clan; Okochi-gosho, Okochi clan; Fujikata-gosho, Fujikata clan; Sakauchi-gosho, Sakauchi clan; Namise-gosho; Tamaru-gosho, Tamaru clan,Iwauchi-gosho, Iwauchi clan.

In addition, even common vassalic houses of the Kitabatake clan also named their residences using the denomination, gosho and clan, as follows: Kozukuri-gosho, Kozukuri clan; Okochi-gosho, Okochi clan; Fujikata-gosho, Fujikata clan; Sakauchi-gosho, Sakauchi clan; Namise-gosho; Tamaru-gosho, Tamaru clan,Iwauchi-gosho, Iwauchi clan.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: In addition, even more plebeian homes of branches of the Kitabatake clan were named using the 'gosho' (manor) convention: Kozukuri-gosho (Kozukuri clan residence), Okochi-gosho (Okochi clan residence), Fujikata-gosho (Fujikata clan residence), Sakauchi-gosho (Sakauchi clan residence), Namise-gosho; Tamaru-gosho (Tamaru clan residence) and Iwauchi-gosho (Iwauchi clan residence).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。
